Thanks for reporting this issue.

I'm looking at the code and I wonder if / how this ever worked since that code seems incorrect and would throw on every instantiation.

I'm trying to fix the driver since I thought it may be an easy fix, but it looks like the driver was never really fully implemented and working. I fixed the region issue, but it looks like there are many other issues as well: > NoSuchVersionThe requested version (2015-10-01) of service ManagedProxyService does not exist14ec4ef4-54f9-461f-aede-717b828f4fbe I will push a branch with WIP changes, but as I said above, it likely needs much more work to get everything working.

With #1635, instantiating the driver and authenticating with the API now works, but I haven't tested much else and it's likely that other things are not working as well since we have no unit tests for this driver to verify the correctness.

`libcloud.compute.drivers.ec2.RESOURCE_EXTRA_ATTRIBUTES_MAP["image"].update({"creation_date": {"xpath": "creationDate", "transform_func": libcloud.utils.iso8601.parse_date}})`

One easy solution is setting:
```py
self.connection.gce_params = {'maxResults': 1500}
```
before this line:
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/gce.py#L2630

In this case, let's please just add a comment to the new function which clarifies how it differs from the ``request_aggregated_items``. Something along the lines that both methods handle pagination, but ``request_aggregated_items`` is meant to be used with operations which operate on a zone or in an aggregated fashion across all the zones whereas the former is used for operations which don't operate on a zone.

I guess one think we could perhaps do is update the S3 driver code to emit a warning on this in case the object name contains a leading slash.

As I said above, long term I do think we should probably change the default behavior, but this may break / change some of the code which depends on the old behavior - so we would need to do it in a major release and still leave that constant in place so user can revert it back in case it breaks their code.

I would actually expect libcloud to raise an `ObjectDoesNotExistError` when the double slash is removed from the object path, but this is probably hard to implement since AWS still returns a response with status 204 even if the object isn’t deleted. This would also immediately break any code that expects the `delete_object` function to return True for objects that don’t exist. So maybe a warning would be enough for now and then this change can be made in a new major release.

@brookewhite9 Only a single test file depends in ``libvirt-python`` so if you can't install it, you should still be able to run rest of the tests (you can comment out that requirement in tox.ini).

Sadly we don't have docs on running integration tests at this point - it relies on credentials to be set for a couple of providers, something which most uses don't have.

Here is a link to how those tests run on CI - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/.github/workflows/integration-tests.yml#L78.

You should be able to run Azure Storage tests using this command:

```bash
pytest -rsx -vvv --capture=tee-sys -o log_cli=True --durations=10 integration/storage/test_azure_blobs.py 
```

By default, this will only run tests which don't need access to Azure, but utilize local Azurite containers. If you want to run tests against actual Azure endpoints, you need to set the following environment variables:

* AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET
* AZURE_CLIENT_ID
* AZURE_TENANT_ID
* AZURE_SUBSCRIPTION_ID

Technically, you could also push your changes (new tests) to this branch and rely on the CI runs, but this process may be very slow and inefficient.
